definitions: actively engaged in or prepared for fighting or warfare
of or relating to armed conflict or military engagement
examples: The combatant forces clashed at the border
Several combatant nations entered the conflict
Combatant status determines treatment under international law
The treaty distinguishes combatant and non-combatant vessels

definitions: eager or quick to fight, argue, or engage in conflict
characterized by an aggressive or confrontational approach in debate or discussion
examples: His combative attitude made negotiations difficult
The boxer maintained a combative stance throughout
She adopted a combative tone during the meeting
The senator's combative style alienated potential allies

definitions: having been arranged or styled by drawing a comb through
having been searched through systematically and thoroughly for something
examples: His neatly combed hair gleamed in the sunlight
The combed wool felt soft and smooth
Police combed the area for evidence all morning
Volunteers combed through the wreckage looking for survivors

definitions: brought together or merged to form a single unit or substance
involving the joint action or effort of two or more parties
examples: The combined ingredients created a delicious flavor
Their combined wealth exceeded ten million dollars
The combined forces launched a massive offensive
A combined effort from all departments solved the problem

definitions: able to catch fire and burn easily when exposed to flame or heat
likely to become violent or lose control suddenly in emotional situations
examples: Store combustible materials away from heat sources
The warehouse contained highly combustible chemicals
The combustible political atmosphere worried observers
His combustible temper made him unpredictable

definitions: providing physical ease and relaxation; free from hardship or pain
having enough money to live without financial worry or stress
feeling relaxed and free from constraint, anxiety, or embarrassment
examples: The comfortable chair supported her aching back perfectly
These comfortable shoes are perfect for long walks
They live a comfortable life on their retirement income
The family maintains a comfortable standard of living
She felt comfortable speaking in front of the group
He's comfortable with the new software already

definitions: having received sympathy or consolation in times of distress or sadness
having been made to feel physically or emotionally comfortable and secure
examples: The comforted child stopped crying in her mother's arms
He felt comforted by their kind words
Patients were comforted by the warm blankets
She was comforted knowing her family was safe

definitions: giving a feeling of relief or encouragement to someone in distress
making someone feel less worried or anxious about something
examples: Her comforting words helped ease his grief
The comforting presence of friends made a difference
It's comforting to know help is available
The doctor's comforting manner calmed nervous patients

definitions: amusing or funny, especially in a way that provokes laughter
of or relating to comedy as a genre or form of entertainment
examples: His comic timing made the audience roar with laughter
The comic mishap lightened the tense atmosphere
She prefers comic roles to dramatic ones
The comic opera delighted audiences for decades

definitions: causing laughter through humor, especially of an exaggerated or absurd kind
so inappropriate or inadequate as to be laughably ridiculous
examples: His comical expressions had everyone laughing
The cat's comical attempts to catch the laser amused us
Their comical misunderstanding of the rules caused chaos
It was comical how seriously he took the game

definitions: about to happen or occur in the near future
approaching or drawing near to a particular place or position
examples: The coming winter promises to be harsh
She's preparing for the coming examination
The coming storm forced everyone indoors
Watch for coming traffic before crossing

definitions: having or showing the confidence and authority to give orders and expect obedience
impressively large or elevated, inspiring respect through size or grandeur
having a position of advantage that allows control or dominance over others
examples: Her commanding voice silenced the room instantly
The general's commanding presence inspired the troops
The castle occupies a commanding position on the hilltop
From the commanding heights, they surveyed the valley
She took a commanding lead in the race
The team holds a commanding position in the league

definitions: serving to honor and remember a person, event, or achievement from the past
examples: The commemorating ceremony honored fallen soldiers
A commemorating plaque marks the historic site
Museums commemorating the civil rights movement opened nationwide
The commemorating exhibition attracted thousands of visitors

definitions: intended to honor and preserve the memory of a person or event
created or done to mark and celebrate an important anniversary or occasion
examples: They issued commemorative stamps for the centennial
The commemorative monument stands in the town square
A commemorative edition of the book was published
She received a commemorative medal for her service

definitions: deserving praise and approval for being good or admirable in quality or action
examples: Her commendable efforts to help others impressed everyone
The team showed commendable dedication to the project
It's commendable that you admitted your mistake
Their commendable honesty saved the company from scandal

definitions: corresponding in size, extent, amount, or degree to something else; proportionate
examples: Salary should be commensurate with experience and qualifications
The punishment was commensurate with the crime
They received rewards commensurate to their contributions
Risk levels are commensurate with potential returns

definitions: connected with or engaged in commerce and the buying and selling of goods
having profit rather than artistic or other value as a primary aim
designed to appeal to a large market rather than specialized audiences
examples: Commercial activity increased during the holiday season
The commercial district bustles with shoppers
The film was a commercial success despite poor reviews
They rejected commercial considerations for artistic integrity
Commercial television relies heavily on advertising revenue
The band's commercial sound appealed to mainstream audiences

definitions: exploited or managed primarily for financial gain rather than other values
examples: The once-authentic festival became heavily commercialised
Critics argue that education has become too commercialised
The commercialised healthcare system prioritizes profit
Traditional crafts risk becoming commercialised for tourists

definitions: exploited or managed primarily for financial gain rather than other values
examples: The beach resort became highly commercialized over time
Christmas has become increasingly commercialized
Commercialized sports focus on revenue over tradition
The commercialized art world alienated many artists

definitions: given official authority or rank, especially in the armed forces
specially ordered or requested to be created for a specific purpose or person
examples: Commissioned officers lead military units
The commissioned study examined environmental impacts
The commissioned artwork adorns the lobby
They commissioned portrait hangs in the gallery

definitions: feeling dedication and loyalty to a cause, activity, job, or person
having made a binding promise or entered into an obligation to do something
examples: She's deeply committed to environmental protection
The committed volunteers worked tirelessly
We're committed to delivering the project on time
The company is committed to reducing emissions

definitions: having plenty of room and space; comfortably and conveniently spacious
examples: The commodious house easily accommodated their large family
Passengers enjoyed the commodious seating arrangements
The commodious storage area held all their equipment
They moved to more commodious offices downtown

definitions: occurring, found, or done often and in many places; prevalent
shared by, belonging to, or affecting two or more people or things
lacking special distinction, rank, or status; ordinary and unremarkable
examples: Rain is common in this region during spring
It's a common mistake among beginners
They discovered their common interest in jazz
The two nations share a common border
He rose from common origins to great success
Don't use common salt for this recipe

definitions: not unusual or special but ordinary and happening or existing in many places
examples: Smartphones have become commonplace in modern society
Such accidents were commonplace before safety regulations
Her commonplace observations added nothing to the discussion
The once-revolutionary technology is now commonplace

definitions: shared by all members of a community; for common use by everyone
relating to or characteristic of a commune or community living arrangement
examples: The communal kitchen serves all residents
They tend the communal garden together
The communal lifestyle appealed to young idealists
Several families lived in communal harmony

definitions: able to be transmitted from one person or organism to another through direct or indirect contact
examples: Measles is a highly communicable disease
The hospital isolated patients with communicable infections
Some communicable diseases spread through airborne particles
Proper hygiene prevents many communicable illnesses

definitions: willing and able to talk or impart information readily and clearly
relating to the ability to convey or exchange information, ideas, or feelings
examples: She's much more communicative after her morning coffee
The communicative child eagerly shared his adventures
Strong communicative skills are essential for this position
The course improved their communicative competence

definitions: relating to or supporting communism as a political and economic system
examples: The communist party won the election
They studied communist economic theory
Several communist countries changed systems after 1989
The communist manifesto influenced many movements

definitions: closely and neatly packed together, having all necessary parts fitted into small space
having a solid, dense structure or build without wasted space or material
examples: The compact car fits easily in tight parking spaces
She carries a compact mirror in her purse
The athlete's compact build gave him an advantage
The compact soil was difficult to dig through

definitions: able to be likened to another; similar enough in relevant aspects to allow comparison
examples: The two products offer comparable quality at different prices
Her skills are comparable to those of experienced professionals
We need comparable data from both studies
There's no comparable example in recent history

definitions: measured or judged by estimating similarity or dissimilarity relative to something else
involving or based on comparison between two or more things
examples: The comparative advantage of local manufacturing is clear
She teaches comparative literature at the university
After comparative analysis, we chose the second option
The comparative study revealed significant differences

definitions: feeling or showing sympathy and concern for the suffering or misfortunes of others
examples: The compassionate nurse comforted anxious patients
Her compassionate response helped ease their grief
The judge took a compassionate view of the circumstances
Compassionate leaders inspire loyalty and trust

definitions: able to exist or work together without conflict or problems
able to be used together or connect without modification in technical systems
examples: Their compatible personalities made them great roommates
The two theories are not compatible with each other
This software is compatible with most operating systems
Check if your device is compatible before purchasing

definitions: evoking interest, attention, or admiration in a powerfully irresistible way
having a powerful and irresistible effect that forces belief or action
examples: She presented compelling evidence for her theory
The prosecutor made a compelling case
The novel's compelling narrative kept readers engaged
He gave a compelling performance in the lead role

definitions: having received payment or other benefits in return for work or loss
having been offset or counterbalanced by an opposing force or effect
examples: Employees were fairly compensated for overtime work
Victims were compensated for their losses
The lack of experience was compensated by enthusiasm
Her weak voice was compensated by excellent acting

definitions: having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully
having legal authority or mental capacity to make decisions or give testimony
examples: She's a competent driver with years of experience
The competent staff handled all issues efficiently
The court declared him competent to stand trial
Only competent authorities can make this decision

definitions: relating to or characterized by competition between rivals
able to compete successfully with others in quality or price
having a strong desire to win or be more successful than others
examples: The competitive market drives innovation
Competitive sports teach valuable life lessons
They offer competitive prices on all products
Her competitive salary attracted top talent
His competitive nature made him a successful athlete
She's too competitive to enjoy casual games

definitions: showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements, unaware of danger
examples: Don't become complacent about your success
The complacent management ignored warning signs
Their complacent attitude led to preventable mistakes
Complacent voters stayed home on election day

definitions: expressing dissatisfaction, pain, or resentment, typically in an annoying way
examples: The complaining customer demanded to see the manager
Her complaining tone irritated her colleagues
Stop your complaining and find a solution
The complaining passengers delayed the departure

definitions: combining in such a way as to enhance or emphasize each other's qualities
given or supplied free of charge as a courtesy or favor
examples: Their complementary skills made them excellent partners
The complementary colors created a striking design
Guests receive complementary breakfast with their stay
The airline offers complementary beverages during flights

definitions: having all the necessary or appropriate parts; entire and whole
to the greatest extent or degree; total and absolute in extent
having been finished or ended; fully carried out or accomplished
examples: The complete collection includes all first editions
She owns the complete works of Shakespeare
The experiment was a complete failure
He showed complete disregard for the rules
The complete renovation took six months
Once complete, the project exceeded expectations

definitions: having been finished or brought to an end with all necessary parts done
examples: The completed manuscript was sent to publishers
All completed forms should be submitted today
She reviewed the completed project with satisfaction
The completed building stands forty stories tall

definitions: in the process of finishing or making whole by adding what is needed
examples: Students completing their degrees must submit final papers
The completing phase of construction begins next month
Workers completing the installation need more materials
She's completing her third novel this year

definitions: consisting of many different and connected parts that work together
not easy to analyze, understand, or explain due to intricacy or involvement
examples: The complex machine required specialized maintenance
Complex organisms evolved from simple cells
The situation is more complex than it appears
She enjoys solving complex mathematical problems

definitions: meeting or willing to meet rules, standards, or laws set by authority
inclined to agree with others or obey rules, especially to an excessive degree
examples: All products must be compliant with safety regulations
The compliant software meets industry standards
The compliant child never questioned authority
She was too compliant to voice her objections

definitions: consisting of many interconnected parts or elements that make understanding or dealing with it difficult
examples: The complicated instructions confused many users
Their complicated relationship defied simple explanation
Tax laws have become increasingly complicated
The surgery involved a complicated procedure

definitions: involved with others in an illegal activity or wrongdoing, sharing responsibility
examples: Several officials were complicit in the corruption scheme
The board was complicit in hiding the losses
Their silence made them complicit in the deception
Anyone complicit in the fraud faces prosecution

definitions: expressing a compliment; praising or approving of someone or something
given or supplied free of charge as a courtesy or business promotion
examples: She made complimentary remarks about his presentation
The review was highly complimentary
Hotel guests receive complimentary wifi access
They sent complimentary tickets to VIP guests

definitions: having one's feelings and expression under control; calm and confident
having been created or written; made up of various parts or elements
examples: She remained composed despite the shocking news
The composed speaker handled tough questions well
The committee is composed of industry experts
Water is composed of hydrogen and oxygen

definitions: made up of various parts, elements, or ingredients combined together
examples: The composite material combines strength with flexibility
Scientists created a composite image from multiple photos
The composite score reflects all test components
A composite sketch helped identify the suspect
